questions.question: Question 1: What is the length of the eustachian tube?
questions.explanation: The length of the eustachian tube is 36 mm (Bony part: 12 mm and Cartilaginous part: 24 mm). It is directed forward, downward, and medially with an angle of 45° to the horizontal axis. Note: The eustachian tube in infants is 18 mm, i.e. about half the size of an adult eustachian tube.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is false regarding the eustachian tube?

options.c: Outer 1/3rd is bony and inner 2/3rd is cartilaginous

questions.explanation:
244 
Sold by @itachibot The eustachian tube also called the auditory or pharyngotympanic tube connects the nasopharynx 
with the tympanic cavity. It is 36 mm long in adults and is divided into two parts: • Bony part - forms the outer one-third of the tube as it is located near the middle ear and is 12 
mm in size. • Fibrocartilaginous part - forms the inner two-third as it is located near the nasopharynx and is 
24 mm in size. In the middle ear it opens in the anterior wall and in the nasopharynx it opens 1-1.25 cm posterior 
to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is the narrowest part of the eustachian tube?
questions.explanation:
The narrowest part of the eustachian tube is the isthmus. It is the junction of the bony and 
cartilaginous parts. Infundibulum is not a part of eustachian tube. 245 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: You are an intern asking a patient to perform a Valsalva manoeuvre for the relief of an ear 
block. Which of the following structure helps in opening the eustachian tube during this 
manoeuvre?
questions.explanation:
Tensor veli palatini helps in opening the Eustachian tube during the Valsalva manoeuvre. It is closed at rest and opens intermittently during swallowing, yawning and sneezing. Opening of the tube • The medial fibres of the tensor veli palatini are attached to the lateral lamina of the tube and 
contract to open the tubal lumen. It is also called the dilator tubae muscle. • Accessory muscles for opening are levator veli palatine & salpingopharyngeus Closure of the tube • It is mainly due to the elastic recoil of the cartilage aided by the high degree of elastin on the 
roof. Ostmann’s pad of fat helps to keep the tube closed. 246 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A child presented with recurrent attacks of acute otitis media. Which of the following 
properties of the eustachian tube predisposes to this?
questions.explanation:
The Eustachian tube in children is wider, shorter (13-18mm), and more horizontal. The 
cartilaginous part is flaccid due to less elastin. The above differences make children more prone to retrograde reflux of nasopharyngeal 
secretions and middle ear infections. In infants along with the secretions, the milk also refluxes 
back while feeding in the supine position.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is a cause for functional eustachian tube obstruction?
questions.explanation:
247 
Sold by @itachibot Cleft palate is a cause for functional Eustachian tube (ET) obstruction. Eustachian tube obstruction can be mechanical, functional or both. Mechanical obstruction can 
result from intrinsic causes such as inflammation or allergy or extrinsic causes such as tumour or 
adenoids. Functional obstruction is caused by collapse of the tube due to increased cartilage 
compliance or failure of active tubal opening mechanism due to poor function of tensor veli 
palatini. In the cleft palate, the obstruction is due to high elastin content at torus tubaris and the poor 
function of tensor veli palatini.

questions.question:
Question 8: You are evaluating the patency and function of the Eustachian tube in a patient with a right 
earache and ear block. Which of the following test you will not do?
questions.explanation:
Stenger test is not used for the assessment of patency or function of the eustachian tube. It is used 
to detect malingering of hearing loss. Tests of Eustachian tube patency: • Pneumatic otoscopy • Nasopharyngoscopy • Valsalva manoeuvre • ET catheterization • Politzer test. Tests of Eustachian tube function: • Toynbee’s test • Tympanometry • Saccharine/dye tests in perforated ears • Sonotubometry.

questions.question:
Question 9: An ENT resident is performing the following maneuver in a patient as shown in the image. 
Which of the following is false regarding the same?

options.a: It builds negative pressure in the nasopharynx

questions.explanation:
The given image depicts the Valsalva manoeuvre and it builds up positive pressure in the 
nasopharynx and not negative pressure. In this test, the patient is asked to close the mouth and nostrils and blow. This produces positive 
pressure within the nasopharynx which opens the patent eustachian tube and is confirmed by the 
tympanic membrane bulge via otoscopy. It is used to assess the Eustachian tube patency and to auto-inflate the middle ear. It is contraindicated in: • Atrophic tympanic membrane as it might get ruptured. • URTI as the infection can spread into the middle ear. 248 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: An otolaryngologist is performing the following procedure in a patient. Which of the 
following is true about this procedure? 241 
Sold by @itachibot

options.d: Used to instill medications into middle ear

questions.explanation:
The procedure depicted in the image is Eustachian tube (ET) catheterization and it uses Politzer’s 
bag and an ET catheter. The catheter is passed along the nasal floor and manoeuvred into the ET opening and the bag is 
insufflated. The outward movement of the tympanic membrane is then noted with an otoscope. It is an unsafe and outdated ET function test. It can lead to complications like TM rupture, 
scarring of ET, epistaxis, spread of nasal/pharyngeal infection to the middle ear. In the methylene blue dye test, the dye is instilled into the middle ear and the time taken by it to 
stain the pharynx is noted. Politzer test is a non-invasive alternative for this and works on the same principle. It uses a nasal 
olive instead of a catheter and is useful in children who can’t perform the Valsalva or Toynbee 
test.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 3-year-old child was brought to the OPD with fever, earache, and poor feeding after an 
episode of URTI. You suspect this as acute suppurative otitis media due to an eustachian tube 
defect. Which is the most accurate test to detect this?
questions.explanation:
Tympanometry is the most accurate test to assess eustachian tube (ET) dysfunction. It is an 
objective measure of ET function and does not rely on patient cooperation. In this test, the movement of TM is visualized to the variation in external canal pressure. The 
disadvantage is middle ear pathologies can overshadow ET function.

questions.question:
Question 12: A middle-aged retropositive woman presented with complaints of hearing her own voice and 
breath sounds with ear fullness. She has lost significant weight in the past 6 months. What is 
the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario describes autophony which is seen patulous eustachian tube. Autophony is a symptom where the patient hears his own voice and breath sounds. Patulous eustachian tube is usually idiopathic where the tube is abnormally patent. But it is also 
seen in rapid weight loss, pregnancy especially the third trimester and patients with multiple 
sclerosis. Treatment includes weight gain, administration of potassium iodide solution. In long-standing 
cases, specific treatment could include cauterization of tubes or insertion of the grommet. Option A: In HIV-related psychosis, there will be persecutory delusion, hallucination, and no ear 
fullness. Option B: The autophony of superior canal dehiscence syndrome usually involves hearing their 
own voice but not their breathing when compared with patients who have patulous eustachian 
tube. Option D: Patient with blocked eustachian tube does not present with autophony. 249 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: For a patient to get barotraumatic otitis media, what is the critical level of the atmospheric 
pressure required?
questions.explanation:
The critical level of the atmospheric pressure required to cause barotraumatic otitis media is 90 
mm Hg. At this point, the atmospheric pressure is higher than the middle ear and it causes the eustachian 
tube blockage.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following activities is least likely to cause otitic barotrauma?
questions.explanation:
A pilot performing take-off (i.e. rapid ascent in the air) is least likely to cause otitic barotrauma 
compared to other options. The usual causes for otitic barotrauma are • Rapid descent during air travel (skydiver) • Underwater diving (scuba diving) • Compression in a pressure chamber (hyperbaric oxygen therapy).

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is not a feature of otitic barotrauma?
questions.explanation:
Hyperacusis is not a feature of otitic barotrauma. Otitic barotrauma is a non-suppurative condition resulting from the failure of the eustachian tube 
to maintain middle ear pressure at ambient atmospheric level. It is usually caused by rapid 
descent during air flight, underwater diving or compression in the pressure chamber. • Severe earache, deafness, and tinnitus are common complaints. • The TM appears retracted and congested. It can get ruptured in severe cases. • The middle ear may show air bubbles or hemorrhagic effusion. • Hearing loss is usually conductive. • Rarely, there is a rupture of labyrinthine membranes causing vertigo and sensorineural hearing 
loss. 250 
Sold by @itachibot Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests
